members.description: Hello, o/ My name is Caio, I am a technology enthusiast, geek, otaku, and a soccer fan. My research focuses on analyzing social aspects in developers' discussions on pull requests and their impact on design decay. Additionally, I am pursuing a Ph.D. in Computer Science at PUC-Rio, with a research focus on investigating the relation between social aspects and software quality.  Finally, I am a member of the OPUS research group at PUC-Rio's Software Engineering Laboratory. With over 9 years of industry experience, I have developed a strong expertise in software development, which  encompass back-end development using Python and Java, full-stack development for Android, and proficiency in working with SQL and non-SQL databases like Firebase, PostgreSQL, and MongoDB. Throughout my career, I have engaged in diverse projects, encompassing the following areas: (i) I have contributed to the development of automatic refactoring tools, enhancing the efficiency and maintainability of software systems. (ii) I have designed and implemented various Android applications, leveraging my expertise in mobile development. (iii) I have built data analytic systems using Python, enabling data-driven insights and decision-making. (iv) I have utilized Spring Boot to develop robust back-end solutions, ensuring seamless integration and efficient functionality.

Katia Romero Felizardo was awarded a PhD in Computer Science from the University of São Paulo (ICMC-USP)  in 2012. She then initiated a full-time academic career, carrying out research in the areas of empirical software engineering. The research areas she has focused on are systematic literature review and evidence-based software engineering. She has, to date, published more than 70 research publications, which include 17 journal papers and one book. She has been a PC member at more than ten conferences and workshops and an editorial board member of some of the leading journals in software engineering.

A PhD Student in PUC-Rio (Brazil), currently doing a sandwich doctorate in Northern Arizona University. In my masters degree, I studied design decay (code metrics, smells, and refactoring) by mining open-source repositories. Currently I'm working on mining open-source repositories to study human aspects of software engineering (e.g., toxicity, sentiment, personality, etc.).
PhD student researching skill set development with Large Language Models and with a research background in Machine Learning

I am currently Ph.D. Student at Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro - PUC-Rio, concurrently enrolled in a sandwich doctorate program at Northern Arizona University - NAU. My research focuses on exploring non-functional requirements and human factors within the realm of open source software.

I am an Assistant Teaching Professor at the Northern Arizona University since August 2022. I have a Master's degree in Computer Sciences from the State University of Maringá - Brazil (2009) and a Ph.D. in Informatics and Computer from the Northern Arizona University - USA (2020). Before joining the NAU, I worked as a Lecturer at the Federal University of Technology - Paraná, Campus Campo Mourão, Brazil for 12 years. I have experience teaching undergraduate courses and advising students in Capstone, research, and extension projects.
I am a NAU Alumni and worked with Dr Gerosa and Dr Igor to reveal the skills newcomers should have to solve open issues in open source software projects

Bianca is an interdisciplinary researcher focused on sustainability within software engineering teams, exploring areas such as Diversity & Inclusion, Technostress, Developer Productivity, and Experience. She specializes in Empirical Software Engineering and has gained significant recognition in her field, serving as the first author of papers published in esteemed venues including ICSE, ESEM, CSCW, IST, TSE, and TOSEM. Her contributions have earned her accolades, such as the Distinguished Paper Award at ICSE Technical Track 2023, the Best Paper Award at ICSE SEIS 2022, and an Honored Mention Award at CSCW 2020, among others. Beyond academia, Bianca is a member of the Steering Committee for the Linux Foundation Software Developer Diversity and Inclusion initiative. With two decades of experience in the IT industry before her research career, Bianca possesses a unique ability to bridge the gap between academia and industry.
projects: Diversity and Inclusion in Open Source

members.description: I am an Assistant Professor in the School of Informatics, Computing, and Cyber Systems at Northern Arizona University. I completed a Ph.D. in Computer Science at the Institute of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of São Paulo in 2015. Previously, I was a visiting scholar at the University of California, Irvine from July 2013 to January 2014. I am also a member of the Software Engineering and Collaborative Systems Research Group from the University of São Paulo, and the Research Group on Information Systems from the State University of Maringá (UEM). I research the intersections of Software Engineering (SE) and Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW). I am intested in diversity and inclusion in Open Source Software development communities, in addition to understanding the impacts of Foundational Models in Education and in Software Development (from a human perspective). I chaired several regional and international events and was part of several PCs, including ICSE, ICSE-NIER, MSR, CSCW, ICGSE, OSS, and EASE.
projects: Diversity and Inclusion in Open Source

members.description: I completed a PhD in Computer Science at the Institute of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of São Paulo in March 2016. I am a Full Professor at the Federal University of Technology - Paraná (UTFPR), Brazil. I was a Visiting Scholar at the University of California, Irvine, from July 2013 to January 2014 and a post-doctoral Scholar at Northern Arizona University (NAU) from July 2019 to February 2021. Most of my research uses AI and Data Science techniques to leverage software engineering tasks.
research_keywords: Supporting newcomers to Open Source Software development
projects: Diversity and Inclusion in Open Source

members.description: Mairieli Wessel is an assistant professor at Radboud University, The Netherlands. Upon receiving her Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of São Paulo (USP), she was awarded the Best Brazilian Ph.D. Thesis on Software Engineering in 2021. Her research interests include software engineering (SE) and computer-supported cooperative work (CSCW). Recent projects include the development of tools and strategies to support open-source software communities and the design of bots and conversational tools.

Ítalo is a Doctoral Student in Informatics and Computing at Northern Arizona University, USA. Master in Computer Science and Computational Mathematics, in the research line of Software Engineering and Information Systems, from the Institute of Mathematical and Computer Sciences (ICMC) of the University of São Paulo (USP). He serves as the representative of NAU's College of Engineering, Informatics, and Applied Sciences (CEIAS) in the graduate student government (GSG). He works as a Teaching Assistant at Northern Arizona University, guiding different project teams to guide them through their capstone project, from planning and requirements analysis to the implementation and testing phase of the project.
projects: Diversity and Inclusion in Open Source

members.description: I am a Professor at the Northern Arizona University (NAU) and a member of the Computer Science Graduate Program at the University of São Paulo (USP), Brazil. I research Human Aspects of Software Engineering and Software Engineering Education. I have been serving on the program committee of important conferences, including ICSE, FSE, MSR, and CSCW. I am one of the general organizers of ICSME 2024 and have been PC Chair/Co-Chair of several events.
projects: Diversity and Inclusion in Open Source

members.description: I am an Undergrad student at NAU going into my Junior year. I'm studying Computer Science, Data Science, and Cyber Security at NAU, expected to finish May 2026, and then hoping to return for a Masters and then a PhD.  I've done a few research projects and personal projects so far, but I'm always looking for more. So far, my main topics of focus have been Website Design, Game Design, and Research into AI, and how we can best use it. I have a love for learning and try to always get all I can out of each day and all experiences! I hope to keep learning more in the future!
I am an undergraduate Software Engineering student at Northern Arizona University. I am assisting with the research and development of a large language model for teaching students how to program.

Misan is a researcher whose work is driven by his avid love and passion for technology, software engineering, and machine learning. Before joining NAU and the RESHAPE Lab, he spent his free time as a contributor to authoritative tech and cybersecurity publications during his undergraduate studies where he graduated with a BSc in Computer Science. His current research focuses on Large Language Models, Software Engineering, and driving the Inclusion of Newcomers & Minorites in Open Source Software Communities

I am a graduate student at Northern Arizona University specializing in Large Language Models (LLMs). My research focuses on the development and application of LLMs to advance natural language processing capabilities and enhance AI-driven solutions.

I hold a BSc (2014) and PhD (2014) in Computer Science from the University of São Paulo. I was a visiting scholar (2016) at Arizona State University. Currently, I am an Assistant Professor at the Aeronautics Institute of Technology in São José dos Campos, São Paulo, Brazil.

Genildo is a PhD Candidate at the Federal University of Amazonas (UFAM), concurrently enrolled in a sandwich doctorate program at Northern Arizona University - NAU. His interests are actually in Audience experience using technologies for interaction and participation in events, User Experience, Design Thinking, Collaborative Systems, and Software engineering. Finally, I am a member of the USES research group at UFAM's Software Engineering and Usability Laboratory.

Maria is a PhD student at the Federal University of Amazonas (UFAM) and is concurrently enrolled in a sandwich doctorate program at Northern Arizona University (NAU). She is currently focused on how companies use Design Thinking, the implementation of Design Thinking within companies, and Design Thinking for requirements elicitation. In the software industry, she works as a software test developer. Finally, I am a member of the USES research group at UFAM's Software Engineering and Usability Laboratory.
I am a Junior majoring in Software Engineering! I am currently contributing to the Gamified OSS lab studies. Our goal is to help students get more comfortable using GitHub.

I am a Software Engineering Senior, and I am working with the IUSE team to create an AI Chatbot to assist computer science students with assignments, while also helping them to improve their thought process and avoiding a violation of academic integrity.
